item.title: [REQ][TUT] Threading in C++?
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

A DWORD is a long, which on nearly every 32-bit CPU in the world is the same as an int, so it dosen’t matter that he used the other one really. I dunno about 64-bit CPUs though, so you should probably use a DWORD.

Read full topic

item.title: [REQ][TUT] Threading in C++?
item.dc:creator: @ilyaostr9 io9
item.description:
@ilyaostr9 wrote:

Aaah, Thanks a bunch, I got it. Only one thing, Javac, it’s not DWORD WINAPI, it’s int, and:

If you want to use multiple threads simultaneously , you have to put WaitForSingleObjectBlahBlah at the end, as seen in this example:

#define WIN32_LEAN_AND_MEAN
#define STRICT
#include <stdio.h>
#include <windows.h>

using namespace std;

DWORD WINAPI ThreadProc(PVOID param)
{
    while(true)
    {
       printf("This message was printed from a different thread\n");
    }
    return 0;
}

DWORD WINAPI ThreadTwo(PVOID param)
{
    while(true)
    {
        printf("A\n");
    }
    return 0;
}

int WINAPI WinMain(HINSTANCE curProc, HINSTANCE nulProc, LPSTR cmdText, int iForgetWhatThisIs)
{
   DWORD dwTid;
   HANDLE hThread = CreateThread(0, NULL, ThreadProc, 0, 0, &dwTid);
   HANDLE hThreadTwo = CreateThread(0, NULL, ThreadTwo, 0, 0, &dwTid);
   WaitForSingleObject(hThreadTwo, INFINITE);     /* To keep from exiting before it finishes */
   WaitForSingleObject(hThread, INFINITE);     /* To keep from exiting before it finishes */
   CloseHandle(hThread);
   CloseHandle(hTreadTwo);
   system("pause");
   return 0;
}

Read full topic

item.title: [REQ][TUT] Threading in C++?
item.dc:creator: @Javacisnotrecognized _^_
item.description:
@Javacisnotrecognized wrote:

[code]
#define WIN32_LEAN_AND_MEAN
#define STRICT
#include <stdio.h>
#include <windows.h>

DWORD WINAPI ThreadProc(PVOID param){
printf(“This message was printed from a different thread”);
return 0xA43D; /* Made up gibberish return value. */
}

DWORD WINAPI WinMain(HINSTANCE curProc, HINSTANCE nulProc, LPSTR cmdText, int iForgetWhatThisIs){
DWORD dwTid;
HANDLE hThread = CreateThread(0, NULL, ThreadProc, 0, 0, &dwTid);
WaitForSingleObject(hThread, INFINITE); /* To keep from exiting before it finishes */
CloseHandle(hThread);
return 0;
}[/code]

That should do something.

Read full topic
